title: Food Preparation — Apple Slicing
description: The child washes, cuts, and serves apple slices. This builds on earlier cutting work with a firmer fruit that requires more controlled pressure.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Wash the apple together.
2. Place on the cutting board. Demonstrate cutting the apple in half (adult may pre-cut).
3. Show the child how to cut a half into slices using a child-safe knife.
4. Remove seeds: 'These are the seeds — remember the life cycle?'
5. Arrange slices on a plate. Optional: dip in yogurt or peanut butter.
6. Enjoy the snack and clean up.
materials_needed: Optional: yogurt or peanut butter for dipping

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the words! Today, we're going to learn how to get an apple all ready to eat, like a super chef! It's going to be yummy!

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands and the apple. Place on tray with cutting board and knife.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our apple adventure! See the round apple? We'll also use a special safe knife, a board to cut on, and a plate to put our yummy slices. And there's a little bowl for the apple seeds! Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we are slicing an apple! Apples are harder than bananas, so we need to press more firmly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we're going to slice an apple! It's a little bit harder than a soft banana, so we'll need to be strong and push down just a little bit harder. We can do it!

slides.text: Demonstrate: hold the apple half flat-side down. Cut into slices. 'Push down slowly and firmly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend we're cutting the apple! Hold the apple half flat on the board, and push the knife down slowly and with a little bit of strength. Watch it go through!

slides.text: 'See the seeds inside? These are apple seeds. If we planted them, a new apple tree could grow!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Ooh, look inside! Those little brown things are seeds. Do you remember how seeds can grow into new plants? If we planted these, maybe a whole apple tree could grow!

slides.text: 'Remove the seeds and put them in the bowl. Arrange your slices nicely on the plate.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take out those seeds and put them in our special bowl. Then, we can make our apple slices look super pretty on the plate. We are making a yummy snack!

slides.prompt: Slice the apple halves into thin slices. Count your slices! Arrange them in a fan shape on the plate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the apple slicer! Take your time and cut the apple pieces. When you're done, let's count how many slices we made and make a pretty fan shape on the plate. You're doing great!

slides.text: Enjoy your apple slices! Wash the cutting board and knife. Compost the core.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely slice a pre-halved apple into even pieces?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! Look at all those yummy apple slices you made! You were so good at slicing, and now you get to eat your delicious snack. Great job being a helper chef today!

parent_notes: Apple slicing is a step up from banana slicing because apples are firmer and require more pressure. The adult should pre-cut the apple in half for safety. Letting the child observe and handle the seeds connects to the plant life cycle curriculum. If the child is ready, they can try cutting the halves themselves with close supervision.

title: Moveable Alphabet — Four-Letter Words (CCVC and CVCC)
description: Building four-letter words with consonant blends: stop, clap, fast, went. The child learns that some words begin or end with two consonant sounds.
instructions:
1. Review CVC words briefly.
2. 'Some words have TWO consonant sounds together at the beginning or end.'
3. Say 'stop': /s/-/t/-/o/-/p/. 'Hear how /s/ and /t/ are right next to each other? That's called a BLEND.'
4. Build: stop, clap, flag, grab, trip.
5. Build end blends: fast, went, lamp, hand, milk.
6. Child reads each word after building.

slides.heading: Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this page! We're going to learn about special words that have four letters. It's like building with words, and we're going to make some super cool ones together!

slides.setup_instructions: Open moveable alphabet. Prepare a clear work space.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some fun things to play with today! We have a box with lots of letter pieces, like building blocks for words. We also have a special mat to build our words on. Ask a grown-up to help you open the letters and get your mat ready!

slides.text: 'You've been building 3-letter words. Now let's try 4-letter words! Listen: STOP. How many sounds? /s/-/t/-/o/-/p/ — FOUR!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We know how to build little words with three sounds, right? Well, today we're going to build bigger words with *four* sounds! Let's listen to the word "stop." Can you hear all the sounds? /s/-/t/-/o/-/p/ — that's four sounds!

slides.text: Build 'stop' together. 'The /s/ and /t/ are blended at the start — we say them close together: st-op.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build the word "stop" with our letters! See how the 's' and 't' sounds are buddies right at the beginning? We say them super fast together, like "st"! Let's put those letters down to make "stop."

slides.text: Build more beginning blends: clap (/k/-/l/-/a/-/p/), flag, grab, trip.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're doing so great! Now let's build some more words that have two sound buddies at the start. We'll build "clap," then "flag," "grab," and "trip." Listen for those beginning sounds that stick together!

slides.text: Now ending blends: fast (/f/-/a/-/s/-/t/), went, lamp, hand. 'Two consonant sounds at the end!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to build words that have two sound buddies at the *end*. Listen to "fast" – /f/-/a/-/s/-/t/. Hear how 's' and 't' are together at the end? We'll build "fast," then "went," "lamp," and "hand."

slides.prompt: Build 5 blend words. Read each one. Can you think of other words that start with /st/ or /cl/?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to build some words all by yourself! Use your letters to build five of those special blend words we learned. After you build each one, try reading it out loud. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You are building longer words now! Blends are two sounds that work together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child segment and build at least 3 four-letter blend words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job building longer words today! We learned that sometimes two sounds like to hold hands and stick together, like in "stop" and "fast." You're becoming a super word builder!

parent_notes: Consonant blends (also called clusters) are two consonants that keep their individual sounds but are said quickly together: st, cl, fl, gr, tr, bl, etc. This is different from digraphs (sh, ch, th) where two letters make one new sound. Blends are a natural progression after CVC words. If the child struggles, slow down the word even more: 's-t-o-p.'

title: Golden Beads — Addition with Exchange Practice
description: Practicing addition with exchange (carrying) using golden bead material, working with larger numbers and multiple exchanges.
instructions:
1. 'Let's add two numbers together! 15 + 17.'
2. First child builds 15 (1 ten bar, 5 units). Second pile: 17 (1 ten bar, 7 units).
3. Combine the ten bars: 1 + 1 = 2 ten bars.
4. Combine the units: 5 + 7 = 12 units. 'But wait — we have MORE than 10 units!'
5. Exchange 10 units for 1 ten bar. Now: 3 ten bars and 2 units = 32!
6. Practice with 2-3 more addition problems.

slides.heading: Golden Bead Addition
slides.subheading: Golden Beads — Addition with Exchange Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun math game we're going to play! We'll use special golden beads that look like shiny gold to learn how to add bigger numbers, like when we get more than 10 of something.

items: Golden bead units and ten bars
slides.setup_instructions: Set up two trays. The child will build each number on a separate tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need for our game! We have shiny golden bead sticks that are like groups of ten, and tiny little golden beads that are just one. We also have numbers and special mats to help us keep everything neat. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Let's add 15 and 17! First, build each number.' Tray 1: 1 ten bar, 5 units. Tray 2: 1 ten bar, 7 units.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we get to build two numbers using our golden beads. We'll make the number 15 with one long ten-stick and five little beads, and then we'll make the number 17 with another ten-stick and seven little beads. It's like building with blocks!

slides.text: 'Now combine them! Put all the ten bars together: 1 and 1 makes 2 ten bars.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put our golden beads together! We'll take the ten-sticks from both numbers and put them together. We have one ten-stick here and another ten-stick there, so when we put them together, we have two ten-sticks!

slides.text: 'Put all the units together: 5 and 7 makes...' Count: '12 units! But 12 is more than 10!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we'll count all the little golden beads. We have five beads from the first number and seven beads from the second number. Let's count them all: one, two, three... up to twelve! Oh my, we have twelve little beads!

slides.text: 'When we have 10 or more units, we EXCHANGE 10 units for 1 ten bar!' Count out 10, trade. 'Now: 3 ten bars and 2 units = 32!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Twelve is a lot of little beads! Remember how we learned that ten little beads can become one big ten-stick? We have twelve beads, so we can take ten of them and trade them for a new ten-stick! Now we have three ten-sticks and just two little beads left. That makes the number 32!

slides.prompt: Try these additions: 13 + 14, 18 + 15, 24 + 19. Build, combine, and exchange when needed!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try some more! We'll do other number puzzles like 13 + 14 and 18 + 15. You get to build the numbers, put them together, and trade ten little beads for a ten-stick if you need to. You can do it!

slides.text: 'When you have 10 or more of something, you can exchange — that's how our number system works!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child combine quantities and exchange 10 units for 1 ten bar?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job adding with the golden beads today! We learned that when we have ten or more of the little beads, we can trade them for a bigger ten-stick – that's how we make bigger numbers work! You're such a super math helper!

parent_notes: This is the golden bead introduction to carrying in addition. The concrete exchange (10 units physically traded for 1 ten bar) makes the abstract concept of 'carrying' visible and logical. Don't worry about writing the algorithm yet — the hands-on work builds deep understanding. The child will repeat this many times before transitioning to paper. Let them verify by counting: 'Is 3 ten bars and 2 units really 32?'

title: Geometric Solids — Bases, Faces, and Edges
description: Examining geometric solids more closely by identifying and counting bases, faces, and edges, and comparing these attributes across solids.
instructions:
1. Present the geometric solids on a tray.
2. Pick up the sphere: 'This is a sphere. It's round everywhere. A ball is a sphere.' Let the child hold it.
3. Pick up the cube: 'This is a cube. It has flat faces and sharp edges. A block is a cube.'
4. Continue with cylinder, cone, pyramid.
5. Three-period lesson for all five.
6. 'Find things in this room that look like these shapes!'
materials_needed: Montessori geometric solids (sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid)

slides.heading: Geometric Solids
slides.subheading: Geometric Solids — Bases, Faces, and Edges
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to learn about special shapes called geometric solids. They're like the shapes of things we can hold and touch!

items: Geometric solids: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid
slides.setup_instructions: Place all 5 solids on a mat or tray. Have extra space for exploration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool shapes! We have a round ball shape, a block shape, a can shape, a party hat shape, and a pointy roof shape. You'll need these shapes and a special mat to play with them. Ask a grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'These are called geometric solids — they are 3D shapes! Let's feel them and learn their names.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready to play with these amazing shapes! We're going to touch them and learn their special names. It's like meeting new friends, and we'll learn all about them together.

slides.text: Sphere: 'Roll it! A sphere rolls in every direction. It has no flat parts.' Cube: 'It has flat FACES and pointy EDGES. Can it roll?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first shape is a sphere! It's like a ball, see how it rolls everywhere? It doesn't have any flat sides or pointy corners. Now, this next one is a cube, like a block, and it has flat sides and sharp corners called edges. Can you make the cube roll?

slides.text: Cylinder: 'It can roll one way! It has two flat circles on the ends.' Cone: 'Pointy on top, round on the bottom.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a cylinder, like a soup can! It can roll one way, and it has two flat circle ends. And look at this fun cone, like a party hat! It's pointy at the top and round at the bottom.

slides.text: Pyramid: 'Flat on the bottom, pointy on top. Its sides are triangles!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This last shape is a pyramid, like a pointy house! It has a flat bottom and triangle sides that go up to a point. We're learning so many cool shapes today!

slides.prompt: Close your eyes — I'll put a shape in your hands. Can you name it just by feeling? Then find objects in the room shaped like each solid!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun game! Close your eyes, and I'll put a shape in your hand. Feel it all over and try to guess its name! After that, we'll look around our room to find real things that look like these shapes!

slides.text: 'You know five 3D shapes! Look for them everywhere — shapes are all around us.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 5 geometric solids and identify at least one real-world example of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning all five of our special 3D shapes today! You can name them and even find them in our room! Remember how the sphere rolled everywhere? Shapes are everywhere, and now you're a shape detective!

parent_notes: Geometric solids give the child vocabulary for the 3D world. Once they know these shapes, they begin to see them everywhere: a can is a cylinder, an ice cream cone is a cone, a box is a rectangular prism. The mystery bag activity (stereognostic sense) is powerful — feeling shape without seeing it builds strong mental imagery. If you don't have wooden solids, gather household objects: ball, block, can, funnel/cone, etc.

title: Read-Aloud: Rosie's Walk by Pat Hutchins
description: Reading 'Rosie's Walk,' a simple picture book where the text says one thing (a hen going for a walk) but the pictures tell a much more exciting story (a fox trying to catch her).
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Rosie the hen. She's going for a walk!'
2. Read the very simple text: 'Rosie the hen went for a walk across the yard...'
3. Let the child LOOK at each picture carefully. 'What's happening to the fox?'
4. The humor is entirely in the pictures — the fox keeps getting into trouble.
5. Re-read and let the child narrate the fox's story.
6. 'The words tell Rosie's story. The pictures tell the fox's story!'

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the special book we're going to read together today! It's called "Rosie's Walk," and it's about a little hen named Rosie. We're going to have so much fun with this story!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together where the child can see the pictures clearly — the pictures tell the real story!
slides.mascot_explanation: To read our story, we need two things: our fun book, "Rosie's Walk," and a super cozy spot for us to snuggle up. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find a comfy place where we can see all the pictures?

slides.text: Show the cover: 'Rosie is a hen. She's going on a walk around her farm. Let's see what happens!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at the very front of our book! See? This is Rosie, a sweet little hen getting ready for a walk. We're going to follow her and see all the fun things she does on her farm today!

slides.text: Read the simple text. But linger on each picture. 'Wait — do you see the FOX? What is he doing?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We’re going to read the words that tell us what Rosie is doing, but we also need to look very, very closely at the pictures. Wait a minute… do you see that sneaky fox hiding? What do you think he's trying to do?

slides.text: Each page: the fox tries to catch Rosie but something goes wrong. Let the child discover and narrate the fox's misadventures.
slides.mascot_explanation: On every page, the fox tries to catch Rosie, but something silly always happens to him! It’s like he keeps getting into little messes. Can you see what happens to the fox on this page?

slides.prompt: Re-read the book. This time, YOU tell me the fox's story! What happens to him on each page?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the storyteller! We'll read the book again, and you can tell me all about what the fox is doing in the pictures. What funny things happen to him when he tries to follow Rosie?

slides.text: 'The words told a simple story, but the pictures told a FUNNY story! Books can tell stories in both words and pictures.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child narrate the fox's story from the pictures?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job telling the fox's story! The words told us about Rosie's walk, but the pictures told us a super funny story about the fox. Isn't it cool how books can tell stories with both words and pictures?

parent_notes: This brilliant book teaches children that pictures carry meaning too. The simple text contrasts with the rich visual narrative, teaching visual literacy. Children love the humor of the fox's repeated failures. It also demonstrates prepositions (across, around, over, past, through) which builds vocabulary. Re-reading is key — children notice new details each time.

title: Geometric Solids — Bases and Faces
description: Exploring the geometric solids more deeply by examining their bases (flat surfaces) and faces. The child traces bases and discovers the 2D shapes hidden within 3D shapes.
instructions:
1. Review the names of the 5 solids.
2. Dip the base of the cube in paint and stamp it on paper. 'What shape is the base? A square!'
3. Stamp the cylinder base: 'A circle!'
4. Stamp the pyramid base: 'A square (or triangle)!'
5. The sphere has no flat base — it can't stamp! 'Why not?'
6. Match each solid to its base outline on paper.
materials_needed: Tempera paint in a shallow dish

slides.heading: Geometric Solids
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big title! It says "Geometric Solids" and talks about "Bases and Faces." That sounds like a fun mystery we get to solve together today!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay paper on the mat. Have paint or pencils ready for base tracing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, good! These are the special toys we need for our game! We have some cool shapes, some colorful paint or a pencil to draw with, and some nice white paper. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get everything ready on our special mat.

slides.text: Review: 'Name each solid as I hold it up.' Then: 'Today we're going to look at the FLAT parts — the bases and faces.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we get to play a guessing game with our shapes! Let's see if we can remember their names. After that, we'll look closely at the flat parts of our shapes – they're called bases and faces!

slides.text: Cube: dip a flat face in paint, stamp on paper. 'A square! The cube has square faces.' Count the faces: 6!
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this block! It's called a cube. We're going to dip one of its flat sides into the paint, like giving it a little bath, and then press it onto the paper. See? It made a perfect square shape!

slides.text: Cylinder: stamp the base. 'A circle!' Cone: stamp the base. 'Another circle!' Pyramid: 'A square on the bottom!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try the other shapes! We'll give the cylinder a paint bath and stamp its flat bottom – what shape do you think it will be? Then we'll do the same for the cone and the pyramid to see what shapes they make!

slides.text: Try the sphere: 'Can we stamp it? No! It has no flat surface. It curves everywhere!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, let's try to give the ball shape, the sphere, a paint bath. Can we make a flat print with it? Nope! It's round and rolls everywhere, so it doesn't have a flat part like the others.

slides.prompt: Trace or stamp every flat face you can find. Label each print: which solid made it? What 2D shape is it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a shape detective! Let's dip and stamp all the flat parts of the shapes we can, and then you can tell me which shape made which picture and what shape it is. You can do it!

slides.text: '3D shapes have 2D shapes hiding inside them! Cubes have squares, cylinders have circles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the base shapes of at least 4 solids?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that big 3D shapes have flat 2D shapes hiding inside them, like magic! You were so good at finding the squares and circles that belong to each shape. High five!

parent_notes: This lesson connects 3D shapes (geometric solids) to 2D shapes (their bases). It's a beautiful conceptual bridge. The stamping/tracing makes the connection concrete — the child can SEE the circle hiding at the bottom of the cylinder. The sphere's inability to stamp teaches through contrast. This prepares for the geometric cabinet work later.

title: Phonetic Reading — CVC Word Lists
description: The child reads lists of CVC words organized by vowel sound. Building reading fluency by practicing decoding multiple words in sequence.
instructions:
1. Prepare word lists grouped by short vowel: -at words, -en words, -ip words, -ot words, -ug words.
2. Start with the -at list: cat, bat, hat, mat, sat, rat, pat, fat.
3. Child reads each word. Time is not important — accuracy is.
4. Move to the -en list: hen, pen, ten, den, men, Ben.
5. Continue through each vowel family.
6. 'How many words can you read in a row?'
materials_needed: CVC word lists organized by word family

slides.heading: Phonetic Reading
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to play a word game today to help us get super good at reading. We'll be reading lots of short words that sound the same at the end, like magic!

items: Printed CVC word lists by vowel family
slides.setup_instructions: Print or write word lists in large, clear letters. One word family per column.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our reading adventure! We have some special word papers, and you can use your finger or a pencil to point to each word. We also have a special mat to keep our papers nice and neat. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to read LOTS of words! Each group has words that rhyme — they have the same ending.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to become word detectives! We'll look at groups of words that sound the same at the end, like a secret code. It's like finding all the toys that belong in the same box!

slides.text: Point to the -at list: 'Read each word. Take your time. Sound it out if you need to.' Cat, bat, hat, mat, sat...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to read our first group of words! See these words that end with "-at"? Let's try to read them together. You can sound them out slowly, like "c-a-t," and then say the word "cat." Take your time, you can do it!

slides.text: Move to -en: hen, pen, ten, den. 'Notice how the ending stays the same — only the first letter changes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job with the "-at" words! Now we're going to look at words that end with "-en." See how only the first letter changes? We still have that "en" sound at the end. You're doing so well!

slides.text: Continue through -ip, -ot, -ug families. Celebrate each list completed!
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to keep going with our word families, finding words that rhyme. We'll read words that end with "-ip," then "-ot," and then "-ug." Every time we finish a group, we'll give ourselves a big cheer!

slides.prompt: Read through all the lists. Put a checkmark next to each word you can read. Count your checkmarks!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you read so many words! Now, let's put a little checkmark next to each word you read all by yourself. Then we can count all your checkmarks to see how many words you know. You're a reading superstar!

slides.text: 'You read SO many words today! You are reading faster and more confidently every week.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 5 words per word family across 3 different families?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did an amazing job reading all those words today! You read them so clearly and with so much confidence. We learned lots of new words and you are getting better and better at reading every single time!

parent_notes: Word list reading builds fluency — the ability to read smoothly and automatically. At this stage, the child is transitioning from laborious sounding-out to quicker recognition. Grouping by word family helps because once the child decodes 'cat,' the pattern carries to 'bat,' 'hat,' etc. Don't rush or time the child; accuracy and confidence matter more than speed right now.

title: Golden Beads — Subtraction Practice with Exchange
description: Practicing subtraction with the golden bead material, including problems that require exchanging (borrowing) across place values.
instructions:
1. Build 38 with golden beads: 3 ten bars and 8 units.
2. 'We have 38. Now let's take away 15. We SUBTRACT.'
3. Remove 1 ten bar and 5 units.
4. 'What's left?' Count: 2 ten bars and 3 units = 23.
5. '38 take away 15 is 23!'
6. Practice with 2-3 more problems (no exchange needed yet).
materials_needed: Golden bead units and ten bars

slides.heading: Golden Bead Subtraction
slides.subheading: Golden Beads — Subtraction Practice with Exchange
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is our special math lesson today! We're going to learn how to take things away, which is called subtraction, using these shiny golden beads. It's like playing a game where we count down!

items: Golden bead units and ten bars
slides.setup_instructions: Set up golden beads and numeral cards on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need for our math game! We have these sparkly golden bead bars that stand for tens, and these little golden beads that stand for ones. We also have some number cards, and we'll use this big mat to keep everything neat. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Addition is putting together. SUBTRACTION is taking away. Let's try it!' Build 38: 3 ten bars, 8 units.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get started! Remember, adding is like getting more, but subtraction is when we take some away. First, let's build the number 38 with our beads. We'll use three of the long ten bars and eight of the little ones.

slides.text: 'We have 38. Now we need to take away 15. First, take away 1 ten bar.' Remove it. 'Now take away 5 units.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we have 38 and we want to take some away. We're going to take away the number 15. First, let's find one of the long ten bars and gently move it off to the side. Then, we need to take away five of the little golden beads.

slides.text: 'What's left? Count what remains: 2 ten bars and 3 units. That's 23!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We took some away, and now we have some left. Let's count what's still here. We have two of the long ten bars and three of the little beads. That means we have 23 left!

slides.text: '38 minus 15 equals 23! Subtraction tells us what's LEFT after we take some away.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we started with 38, and when we took away 15, we ended up with 23 left. Subtraction is super useful because it tells us how much we have after we've taken some away. Isn't that neat?

slides.prompt: Try these: 47 minus 23, 56 minus 31, 69 minus 45. Build, take away, and count what's left!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try some! We'll build the first number, then take away the second number, and count what's left. You can do it! Remember to take away the tens first, then the ones.

slides.text: 'You can add AND subtract with golden beads! Addition puts together, subtraction takes apart.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform simple subtraction (without exchange) using golden beads?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did such a super job with subtraction today! You learned how to take away numbers using the golden beads and count what was left. You're a math superstar, especially when you took away those beads so carefully!

parent_notes: Golden bead subtraction starts with problems that don't require exchange (borrowing). The child physically removes beads, making subtraction concrete and logical. 'Take away' language is intuitive for young children. Once this is comfortable, we'll introduce subtraction with exchange (needing to break a ten bar into units). Don't rush to the abstract — let the child work with the concrete materials many times.

title: Parts of a Plant — The Flower
description: Detailed exploration of the flower and its parts: petals, stem, pistil, stamen. The child dissects a real flower to observe its structures.
instructions:
1. Present a large, simple flower (lily, tulip, or daffodil work well).
2. 'The flower is the part of the plant that makes seeds. Let's look inside!'
3. Point to petals: 'Petals attract bees and butterflies with their colors.'
4. Gently pull apart to find the stamen (pollen producers) and pistil (center).
5. Show pollen — let the child touch it. 'This yellow dust is pollen!'
6. Draw and label the parts of a flower.

slides.heading: Parts of a Plant
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn all about flowers and what's hiding inside them. It's like a special secret garden adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the flower on a white paper to see parts clearly. Have magnifying glass ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: To have our flower adventure, we need a pretty flower, a magnifying glass to see tiny things, paper and crayons to draw, and some special cards. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can start?

slides.text: 'The flower is a very important part of the plant — it's where seeds begin! Let's look inside one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our beautiful flower! It's a very special part of the plant because it's like a little house where new seeds start to grow. Let's take a peek inside and see what's there!

slides.text: Point to the petals: 'These colorful parts are PETALS. They attract insects like bees and butterflies.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these pretty, colorful parts all around the outside? Those are called petals, and they are like a big welcome sign to help attract pretty bugs like bees and butterflies.

slides.text: Gently open the petals: 'These tall parts with fuzzy tops are STAMENS. They hold POLLEN — see the yellow dust?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's gently open up the flower. See those tall skinny parts inside with the dusty tops? Those are called stamens, and they are holding yellow dust called pollen!

slides.text: Point to the center: 'This is the PISTIL. When pollen reaches the pistil, a seed starts to grow!'
slides.mascot_explanation: And right in the very middle, that skinny part is called the pistil. When the yellow pollen from the stamens lands on the pistil, that's how a new seed gets ready to grow!

slides.prompt: Carefully take the flower apart. Use the magnifying glass to examine each part. Draw and label: petals, stamen, pistil.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for some fun! Let's carefully take our flower apart, look at each piece really close with our magnifying glass, and then draw what we see. We'll draw the petals, the stamens, and the pistil!

slides.text: 'Now you know the secret of flowers — they are seed factories! Petals, stamens, pistil — each part has a job.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 parts of a flower and explain the petals' role?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You found all the parts of the flower and learned how they help make seeds. You're a super flower scientist now, and you know about petals, stamens, and the pistil!

parent_notes: Flower dissection is one of the most engaging botany activities. Use large, simple flowers where the parts are easy to see. Lilies and tulips are ideal. The pollen is exciting for children to touch (wash hands after, as lily pollen stains). This connects to the life cycle work — flowers make seeds which grow into new plants. If fresh flowers are unavailable, use detailed photographs.

title: Watercolor — Painting Flowers
description: The child paints flowers using watercolor techniques learned previously. Combining observational drawing with watercolor skills.
instructions:
1. Place a real flower (or picture) as a reference.
2. 'Look carefully at the flower. What shapes do you see? What colors?'
3. Wet the paper lightly.
4. Start with the center: 'A small circle for the middle.'
5. Paint the petals: 'Soft strokes going outward from the center.'
6. Add the stem and leaves. Let colors blend naturally.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we get to be super artists and paint beautiful flowers with watercolors. It's going to be so much fun to see our flowers come to life!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting area. Place the flower where the child can observe it easily.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special art supplies ready! We have our colorful watercolors, special paper that loves water, a brush for painting, and a cup for our water. We also have a real flower to look at, and a smock to keep our clothes clean. Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Let's paint the flower we studied today! Look carefully — what shapes and colors do you see?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, artist! We're going to paint the pretty flower we looked at. Take a good look at it. What shapes do you see? What colors are in our flower? Let's think about it before we start painting.

slides.text: Wet the paper lightly. 'Start in the center — paint a small circle. What color is the center of the flower?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to make the middle of our flower. First, let's make our paper a little wet, like a gentle rain. Then, right in the middle, let's paint a little round circle. What color is the very middle of our flower?

slides.text: 'Now add the petals! Stroke outward from the center. Each petal is like a soft tongue shape.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're painting the flower's petals now! We'll make soft strokes that go out from that little circle we painted. Imagine painting little soft tongues reaching out from the center to make the petals.

slides.prompt: Paint your flower. Add a green stem and leaves. Let the colors blend on the wet paper!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our flower grow! Let's add a green line for the stem going down. Then we'll add some green leaves on the stem. Watch how the colors can mix together on the wet paper, like magic!

slides.text: Let dry. 'Your flower painting is beautiful! Art and science work together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child paint a recognizable flower with center, petals, and stem?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing flower painting! It looks so beautiful, just like the real one. We used our eyes to see and our hands to paint, just like scientists and artists do. You did such a wonderful job painting your flower!

parent_notes: Painting from observation (a real flower) develops different skills than painting from imagination. The child must look carefully and translate what they see into paint. Don't expect botanical accuracy — the goal is observation and expression. Watercolors are forgiving for flowers because the soft edges naturally resemble petals. This connects art to the botany curriculum beautifully.

title: Polishing — Shoe Polishing
description: The child learns to polish a leather shoe, extending the polishing skills to a practical, real-world application.
instructions:
1. Place materials on a tray: old leather shoe, shoe polish or cream, applicator brush, polishing cloth, newspaper.
2. Place newspaper to protect the work surface.
3. Demonstrate: apply a small amount of polish with the brush in small circles.
4. Let it sit briefly, then buff with the cloth.
5. 'See the shine coming back? The polish protects the leather!'
6. Child polishes the other shoe independently.

slides.heading: Polishing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun lesson! We're going to learn how to make shoes shiny and new, just like magic!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table with newspaper. Put on a smock. Place shoes and supplies on tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these things we need for our shoe-shining adventure! We have a shoe to make shiny, some special cream to make it gleam, a brush to spread the cream, a soft cloth to make it sparkle, and some paper to keep our table clean. Don't forget a smock to keep your clothes neat! Ask your grown-up to help you find everything and get ready!

slides.text: 'People have been polishing shoes for hundreds of years! It keeps the leather healthy and looking nice.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know people have been making shoes shiny for a super, super long time? It helps the shoes stay strong and look so handsome, just like you!

slides.text: Demonstrate on one shoe: dip the brush lightly in polish. Apply in small circles over the whole shoe.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch me! We'll use this brush to pick up just a little bit of the shiny cream. Then, we'll gently rub it all over the shoe in little circles, like we're giving it a gentle massage.

slides.text: 'Let the polish sit for a moment. Now take the cloth and BUFF — rub in quick circles until it shines!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We let the cream rest for a tiny bit, and then we take our soft cloth. Now, we rub, rub, rub in circles – watch how it starts to get a beautiful shine! It's like waking up the shoe's sparkle!

slides.text: Compare the polished shoe to the unpolished one. 'See the difference? Now it's your turn with the other shoe!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at this shoe next to the other one! Can you see how much shinier it is now? It's like it went from sleepy to super sparkly! Now it's your turn to make the other shoe just as amazing!

slides.prompt: Polish the second shoe: apply polish, wait, buff to a shine. Compare both shoes when finished!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's your turn to shine! Take your brush and put some cream on the other shoe, then let it rest, and then buff it with the cloth until it sparkles like the first one. Let’s see your beautiful shiny shoes!

slides.text: Clean up materials. Wash hands. 'You polished shoes! This is a skill you can use your whole life.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the shoe polishing process independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You made the shoes so shiny and new, just like a pro! You learned how to polish shoes, and that's something super special you can do for your whole life. Great job!

parent_notes: Shoe polishing is a quintessential Montessori practical life exercise. It teaches care for belongings, following a sequence, and producing a visible result. Use non-toxic shoe cream or a beeswax-based polish. Old adult shoes from a thrift store work perfectly for practice. The before-and-after comparison is deeply satisfying for children.

title: CVC Reading — Labeling the Environment
description: The child reads word labels and places them on matching objects around the room. This brings reading into the real environment.
instructions:
1. Prepare 10-12 word labels for objects in the room: rug, cup, pen, lid, mat, box, bag, hat, fan, bed.
2. Show the child the stack of labels.
3. Child reads the first label: 'rug.' 'Can you find the rug and put this label on it?'
4. Continue with each label.
5. When all are placed, do a 'reading walk' around the room to check.
6. Leave labels up for the day!
materials_needed: 10-12 word labels on cards or sticky notes
Objects in the room that match the words

slides.heading: Reading Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to play a fun game today where we put words on things all around our room. It's like giving everything its own special name tag!

items: 10-12 word labels (rug, cup, pen, lid, mat, box, bag, hat, fan, bed)
slides.setup_instructions: Write words clearly on cards. Ensure the objects are present in the room.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these little cards! These have words on them, and we're going to use them to make our room super smart. We also have some sticky stuff to help the words stay put on our things.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to put WORDS on things! Read each word, find the object, and label it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we get to be word detectives! We'll read the words on these cards and then find the matching thing in our room to put the word on. It's like a treasure hunt for words!

slides.text: Hand the child the first card. 'Read it.' Child sounds out: '/r/-/u/-/g/... rug!' 'Find the rug and tape this word on it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's your first word card, friend! Let's try to sound it out together. /r/-/u/-/g/... rug! Yay, you read it! Now, can you find the rug in our room and stick this word right on it?

slides.text: Continue with each label. The child reads independently and places each one.
slides.mascot_explanation: You are doing so great reading all these words! Keep up the super work finding each thing and putting its word name right on it. We're making our room so full of words!

slides.text: When all labels are placed, walk around together: 'Let's check! This says rug — is it on the rug? Yes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's go on a special word walk together to see all the amazing work you did! We'll point to each word and make sure it's on the right thing, like magic!

slides.prompt: Place all the labels. Then make 3 MORE labels for things I haven't named — you choose the objects and write the words!
slides.mascot_explanation: You've placed all the words so perfectly! Now, let's be super creative and make three more word labels for other things in our room. What cool things do you want to name?

slides.text: 'Our room is full of words now! Reading is everywhere — words name everything around us.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and correctly place at least 8 out of 10 labels?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Our room looks amazing with all the words everywhere! You did such a fantastic job reading and putting words on everything. Now we know that reading can be found all around us, naming all our favorite things!

parent_notes: Environment labeling is a powerful Montessori reading activity because it puts reading in context. The child sees that written words name real things in their world. Leave the labels up for a few days — the child will re-read them naturally. Making their own labels is an exciting extension that combines reading and writing. Gradually add more complex words to the label collection over time.

title: Golden Beads — Building Large Numbers (100-999)
description: Extending golden bead number building to three-digit numbers. The child uses hundred squares, ten bars, and unit beads to build numbers in the hundreds.
instructions:
1. Review: unit, ten bar, hundred square.
2. 'Let's build 245!' Place 2 hundred squares, 4 ten bars, 5 unit beads.
3. Match with numeral cards: '200' + '40' + '5' = 245.
4. Build more: 136, 371, 502, 819.
5. I say a number, child builds it with beads and cards.
6. Child builds a number, I read it.
materials_needed: Golden bead units, ten bars, hundred squares

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special math game where we learn about big numbers, like the ones in your house! We're going to use shiny golden beads to make them.

items: Golden beads: units, ten bars, hundred squares
slides.setup_instructions: Organize beads by category. Stack numeral cards by category.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we need for our game! We have little golden squares, long golden sticks, and tiny golden dots – these help us make big numbers. We also have big number cards! Can you ask your grown-up to help you find all these special treasures?

slides.text: 'We can build numbers in the HUNDREDS! Let's build 245.' Start with hundreds: 'How many hundreds? TWO.' Place 2 hundred squares.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build a super big number! The number is 245. First, we need to find the part that means "hundreds." Since it's 2 hundreds, we put down two of our big golden squares.

slides.text: 'How many tens? FOUR.' Place 4 ten bars. 'How many units? FIVE.' Place 5 unit beads.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're still building 245! Now we need the "tens" part. We need 4 tens, so let's find four of the long golden sticks. Then, for the "units," we need 5 little golden dots.

slides.text: Find the numeral cards: '200' card, '40' card, '5' card. Overlay them: '245! The beads match the number!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we built the number 245 with our golden beads! Now we match it with the number cards. We put the "200" card, the "40" card, and the "5" card together, and look! It makes 245, just like our beads!

slides.text: 'Let's try 502. How many hundreds? FIVE. Tens? ZERO — none! Units? TWO.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build another big number, 502! How many hundreds do we need? That’s right, five golden squares! And how many tens? Zero! So we don't need any golden sticks this time. Then we need two little golden dots for the units.

slides.prompt: Build these numbers: 136, 371, 502, 819. Use beads AND numeral cards for each. Then make up your own!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super builder! We're going to build numbers like 136 and 371. You get to use the golden beads and the number cards to make them, and then you can even make up your own special number!

slides.text: 'You can build numbers all the way to 999! That's almost a thousand!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 3 three-digit numbers with beads and matching cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job building numbers all the way to 999! That's almost like a thousand! You are a super math star for building those big numbers with the golden beads and cards.

parent_notes: Three-digit numbers are a big conceptual leap. The numeral card overlay system is key: the child physically sees that 245 is '200' (hundreds) + '40' (tens) + '5' (units). The zero placeholder (like in 502) is important — the child sees that there are NO tens, but the zero holds the place. This deep place value understanding prevents future confusion with larger numbers.

title: Community Helpers — Firefighters
description: In-depth exploration of firefighters: what they do, their equipment, fire safety rules, and how they help our community.
instructions:
1. Show pictures of firefighters, fire trucks, and fire stations.
2. Discuss their job: putting out fires, rescuing people, teaching fire safety.
3. Talk about their equipment: helmet, turnout gear, hose, axe, oxygen tank.
4. Fire safety rules: 'Stop, drop, and roll. Know your escape plan. Test smoke detectors.'
5. Role-play: pretend to be firefighters responding to a call.
6. Draw a fire truck or firefighter.

slides.heading: Community Helpers
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn all about special people called firefighters who help us. They are super important helpers in our town!

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures and cards. Clear space for role-play.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our firefighter adventure! We have pictures of brave firefighters and their cool gear, and some paper and crayons so we can draw. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get them ready!

slides.text: 'Firefighters are some of our most important community helpers. Their job is to keep us safe from fire!'
slides.mascot_explanation: These pictures show us who firefighters are! They are very important helpers because they keep us safe when there's a fire. They are like superheroes for our community!

slides.text: Show their equipment: 'Helmets protect their heads. Turnout gear protects their bodies from heat. The hose sprays water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See all this special stuff firefighters wear and use? The hat keeps their head safe, the big coat stops them from getting too hot, and the long hose sprays water to put out fires. They have special tools to help people!

slides.text: 'Firefighters also teach us how to be safe. If your clothes catch fire: STOP, DROP, and ROLL!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Firefighters also teach us how to stay safe, which is so smart! If your clothes ever catch on fire, remember to STOP what you're doing, DROP to the ground, and ROLL around to put it out. It's like a special safety dance!

slides.text: Practice stop, drop, and roll together. 'Do you know your family's escape plan if there's a fire?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice that safety dance together: STOP, DROP, and ROLL! Now, do you know what your family would do if there was a fire at home? It's important to have a plan to get out safely.

slides.prompt: Draw a fire truck or a firefighter in full gear. Label the equipment you can name!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our own firefighter art! We can draw a big red fire truck or a brave firefighter with all their cool gear. What colors will you use for your drawing?

slides.text: 'Firefighters are brave helpers. They risk their lives to keep us safe. Let's always be grateful!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name 3 pieces of firefighter equipment and demonstrate stop, drop, and roll?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job learning about firefighters today! You were so good at pretending to be one and drawing your own firefighter. Remember how important they are for keeping us safe!

parent_notes: Fire safety is a critical life skill. Practice your family escape plan and teach the child to call 911 in an emergency. Many fire stations offer tours for young children — this would be an excellent extension. Point out fire trucks when you see them. Discuss smoke detectors at home: 'This beeps if it senses smoke to warn us.'

title: Read-Aloud: Firefighters! by Norma Simon
description: Reading 'Firefighters!' to learn about what firefighters do throughout their day. Connects to the community helpers curriculum.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you know about firefighters already?'
2. Read the book, discussing each page's information.
3. 'Firefighters sleep at the fire station! When the alarm rings, they slide down the pole and jump on the truck!'
4. Discuss: 'What do you think is the hardest part of being a firefighter?'
5. Compare to our community helpers discussion.
6. 'What questions would you ask a real firefighter?'
materials_needed: Firefighters! by Norma Simon (or similar nonfiction firefighter book)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It's the cover of a special book all about firefighters. We're going to read it together and learn all about the brave people who help us.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together. Have the community helper cards nearby for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the things we need for our reading adventure today! We have our book, "Firefighters!", and we need a super cozy spot to sit and read. Maybe you can find your favorite blanket and pillow!

slides.text: Before reading: 'We learned about firefighters today. This book will show us even more about their work!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we start reading, let's remember what we already know about firefighters. We're going to read this book to learn even more cool stuff they do!

slides.text: Read and discuss each page. 'They live at the station! They cook their own meals! They exercise to stay strong!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the book together, page by page. We'll learn that firefighters live at their special house called a fire station, and they even make their own yummy food and do exercises to stay strong!

slides.text: 'When the alarm sounds, they have to get ready in seconds! They practice so they can move FAST.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh wow, listen to this! When the fire alarm rings, firefighters have to get dressed super-duper fast! They practice all the time so they can be quick like a superhero.

slides.prompt: 'If you could ask a firefighter three questions, what would you ask?' Think about it and tell me.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine you could talk to a real firefighter! What three questions would you ask them? Think really hard about what you want to know and then tell me your questions.

slides.text: 'Firefighters work hard every day to keep us safe. Reading taught us so much about their job!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child share 3 facts they learned from the book?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned so many amazing things about firefighters today! They work super hard to keep us all safe, and reading this book helped us understand their important job even better. You did a great job listening and learning!

parent_notes: Nonfiction read-alouds build content knowledge and vocabulary. Children learn that books can give us INFORMATION, not just stories. This is an important distinction for developing literacy. If this specific title is unavailable, any age-appropriate firefighter nonfiction book works. The discussion questions develop critical thinking and curiosity.

title: Sewing — Cross Stitch on Burlap
description: Introduction to the cross stitch. The child learns to make an X pattern on burlap, building on the running stitch foundation.
instructions:
1. Draw a grid of dots on the burlap (or use the natural burlap weave as a guide).
2. Thread the needle with yarn.
3. Demonstrate: stitch diagonally from bottom-left to top-right, then bottom-right to top-left. 'It makes an X!'
4. Show how to repeat the X pattern in a row.
5. Child practices making a row of X's.
6. The child can create initials or a simple design with cross stitches.

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about sewing today. It's like drawing with a needle and thread to make pretty pictures on cloth!

slides.setup_instructions: Mark a grid of evenly spaced dots. Thread the needle and tie a knot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our sewing adventure! We have some bumpy cloth called burlap, a special big needle for yarn, and colorful yarn to make our stitches. We might also use a hoop to hold the cloth still, like a little frame. Ask your grown-up to help you find these special sewing friends!

slides.text: 'You learned the running stitch — straight lines. Today we learn the CROSS stitch — making X's!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned to make a straight line with our needle? That was like a little path! Today, we're going to make something even cooler: a big 'X'!

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'Go from this bottom corner UP to this top corner (diagonal). Now cross over: bottom corner UP to the other top corner. An X!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me do this! We take our yarn from the bottom corner and go all the way up to the top corner, like climbing a little hill. Then, we cross over from the other bottom corner up to the other top corner, and ta-da! We made an 'X'!

slides.text: 'Make another X right next to it. And another! You're creating a row of cross stitches.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's make another 'X' right next to that one! And another one! We're making a whole line of 'X's, like a pattern. It's like building with stitches!

slides.prompt: Sew a row of cross stitches. Then try making your initial letter using cross stitches!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to make some 'X's! First, let's make a whole row of them, just like we practiced. Then, if you want, you can try to make the first letter of your name with your stitches. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Beautiful cross stitching! People have been doing cross stitch for hundreds of years to decorate fabric.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create at least 5 cross stitches in a row?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job sewing those 'X's! Look at your beautiful row of stitches. People have been making these pretty cross stitches for a very, very long time to make fabric look special. You're a super stitcher!

parent_notes: Cross stitch is a natural progression from running stitch. The diagonal movements require more spatial planning. Burlap's open weave makes it ideal for learning. Cross stitch patterns of initials or simple pictures are very motivating. This is a wonderful independent activity and can become a lifelong hobby. Many children find cross stitch deeply calming and meditative.

title: Phonetic Booklets — Reading and Illustrating
description: The child reads a phonetic booklet and creates their own illustrations to accompany the text, deepening comprehension.
instructions:
1. Choose a new phonetic booklet.
2. Child reads the booklet independently (with support as needed).
3. 'Now let's make YOUR version! I'll write the words and you draw the pictures.'
4. Fold paper to make a small book.
5. Write (or child writes) each sentence on a page.
6. Child illustrates each page. They have created their own book!

slides.heading: Phonetic Booklets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to make our very own special books today. It's going to be so much fun to read and draw!

slides.setup_instructions: Fold and staple blank paper to make a small book. Have the phonetic booklet ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some things to make our book! Here's a special little book to read, some plain paper to fold into a book, a stapler to hold it together, and colorful crayons and a pencil for drawing. Ask a grown-up to help you get them ready!

slides.text: 'First, let's read this book.' Child reads the phonetic booklet. Celebrate their reading!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first, we get to read our little book together! Let's use our smart reading eyes and sound out all the words. You're doing such a great job reading!

slides.text: 'Now YOU are going to be the illustrator! An illustrator is the person who draws the pictures for a book.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, guess what? You get to be the artist who draws the pictures! An illustrator is someone who makes the pictures that go with the words in a book, like you will!

slides.text: Write (or help child write) the text on each page of the blank book. One sentence per page.
slides.mascot_explanation: For each page in our new book, we'll write one sentence from the story. This helps us remember what the book is all about.

slides.text: 'Now draw a picture for each sentence. Make it match the words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the best part – drawing! You get to draw a picture for each sentence we wrote. Make your drawing show exactly what the words say!

slides.prompt: Illustrate your whole book! Color carefully. When done, read your book to someone special.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's finish making our book by drawing all the pictures and coloring them in. When we're all done, we can read our amazing book to someone special!

slides.text: 'You made a BOOK! You are a reader AND a bookmaker. That's incredible!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read the text and create relevant illustrations for each page?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You made your very own book by reading the words and drawing the pictures. You are a super reader and a fantastic bookmaker!

parent_notes: Making their own illustrated version of a book connects reading, writing, and art. It deepens comprehension because the child must visualize each sentence to draw it. These homemade books become treasured possessions. Start a child's library of their own books. The pride of authorship motivates further reading and writing. Encourage the child to 'read' their book to siblings, grandparents, or stuffed animals.

title: Linear Counting — Counting Chain of 100
description: The child counts the hundred-bead chain, placing number arrow labels at every ten. Building stamina and understanding of the counting sequence to 100.
instructions:
1. Lay out the hundred chain in a long line on the mat.
2. Begin counting from 1, touching each bead.
3. At every 10th bead, place the arrow label (10, 20, 30...).
4. Count all the way to 100!
5. 'Wow — 100 beads! That is the same as the hundred square!'
6. Compare: fold the chain into 10 rows of 10. Does it match the square?

slides.heading: Counting Chains
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It shows us our special counting tool for today – a big, long chain with lots and lots of beads. We're going to use this to learn all about counting to 100!

slides.setup_instructions: You need a long stretch of floor. Lay the chain straight. Have arrow labels ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some special things to help us count! We have a long chain with 100 beads, and these cool arrow labels that say numbers like 10, 20, and 30. We also need a big space on the floor and a picture of a hundred square. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'This is the HUNDRED chain! It has 100 beads. Let's count every single one and mark the tens!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our super long counting chain! It has 100 beads, which is a LOT! Our job is to count each one, and we'll put a special arrow on every group of ten beads as we go. Let's get ready to count!

slides.text: Count together: '1, 2, 3... 10!' Place the '10' arrow. Continue: '11, 12, 13... 20!' Place the '20' arrow.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start counting together! We'll touch each bead as we say its number, like "1, 2, 3..." all the way to "10!" Then we put down the "10" arrow. We'll keep going, counting "11, 12..." until we reach "20" and put down the "20" arrow.

slides.text: Keep counting! The child may take over independently. Encourage them to continue on their own.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super counter! Keep going with our chain, touching each bead and saying the number. When you get to the next group of ten, put down the arrow label all by yourself! You can do it!

slides.text: At 100: 'ONE HUNDRED! You counted every single bead!' Compare to the hundred square.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We made it all the way to the end! Look, we counted 100 beads – that's a HUGE number! Now, let's find our hundred square picture and see how it matches our long chain.

slides.prompt: Can you fold the chain into rows of 10? Count by tens: 10, 20, 30... 100! Does it look like the hundred square?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a game with our counting chain! Can you fold it up so it makes neat rows, just like the hundred square? We can count by tens: 10, 20, 30... all the way to 100, and see if it looks the same.

slides.text: 'You counted to 100 — every single number! Ten tens make one hundred.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count to 100 along the chain with accurate placement of ten-labels?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You counted all the way to 100, and you put the special number arrows in just the right spots. That means ten groups of ten beads make one big hundred – you’re such a great counter!

parent_notes: Counting the hundred chain is a major accomplishment and a concentration milestone. It typically takes 15-20 minutes and requires sustained focus. Don't rush or interrupt the child during this work. Some children will want to repeat it many times. The comparison to the hundred square (folding the chain into 10 rows) shows that the chain and the square contain the same quantity in different arrangements.

title: Puzzle Map — South America
description: Introduction to the South America puzzle map. The child learns the names and locations of major South American countries.
instructions:
1. Show South America on the world map. 'This is the continent south of North America!'
2. Present the South America puzzle map.
3. Remove Brazil: 'Brazil is the biggest country in South America!' Name its color.
4. Remove Argentina, Peru, Colombia.
5. 'South America has 12 countries!'
6. Focus on 3-4 countries. Replace all pieces.

slides.heading: Puzzle Map
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play with a special puzzle today that shows us a big place called South America. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Place both maps on the table. Point out South America on the world map first.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our puzzle adventure! We need our South America puzzle, a big world map, and a special picture that shows us where everything goes. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things?

slides.text: Show South America on the world map: 'This is South America — pink! It's connected to North America.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big world map? We're going to find a special pink place called South America. It's like a neighbor to another place we know, North America!

slides.text: Open the continent map. Remove Brazil: 'Brazil is HUGE! It takes up almost half the continent!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at our South America puzzle. We're going to take out the biggest country first, called Brazil. Wow, it's super, super big, isn't it?

slides.text: Remove Argentina: 'Argentina is at the bottom, reaching toward Antarctica.' Remove Peru and Colombia.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to find a few more friends. We'll take out Argentina, which is way down at the bottom, and then Peru and Colombia.

slides.text: 'South America has the Amazon River — the biggest river in the world! And the Andes Mountains — very tall!'
slides.mascot_explanation: South America is a super special place! It has the longest river, called the Amazon, and really, really tall mountains called the Andes. Imagine how high they go!

slides.prompt: Remove the countries you learned. Can you put them all back? Name each one as you place it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to be the puzzle expert! Take out the countries we learned about and then try to put them back in their right spots. Say their names as you put them in – you can do it!

slides.text: 'You know countries in TWO continents now — North America and South America!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place at least 3 South American countries?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You know so many countries in South America now, and you already know countries in North America too! You are such a super smart explorer!

parent_notes: South America is the natural second continent to study after North America because of their connection. Brazil is fascinating for children because of its size and the Amazon rainforest. If your family has South American heritage, highlight that connection. Fun fact: South America has the Amazon River and the Andes Mountains — introduce these with excitement!

title: Printmaking — Potato Stamps
description: The child carves simple designs into potato halves and uses them to create repeating prints and patterns.
instructions:
1. Cut a potato in half. The adult carves a simple shape (star, heart, circle) into the flat surface by cutting away the background.
2. Show the child the raised design.
3. Dip in paint, press on paper, lift. 'A star print!'
4. Child creates a repeating pattern using the stamps.
5. Make a second potato stamp with a different design.
6. Combine both stamps in a pattern.

slides.heading: Printmaking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make some super cool art today using potatoes! It's called printmaking, and it means we'll use our potato shapes to make lots of pictures.

slides.setup_instructions: Adult pre-carves designs into potato halves. Set up painting area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our special art project! We have potato shapes that are ready to make prints, yummy paint to use, and some paper to make our pictures on. We also have a smock to keep our clothes clean and paper towels for little messes, just in case! Ask a grown-up to help you find all these fun things.

slides.text: 'Look at this potato — I carved a star shape into it! The star sticks up and everything else is cut away.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this special potato! See how there's a shape, like a star, that's sticking up? That's the part that will make our print, like a secret stamp! We can't wait to see what it makes on the paper.

slides.text: Dip the potato in paint. Press firmly onto paper. Lift straight up. 'A star print!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make a print! We'll gently dip the potato shape into the paint, then press it down on the paper. When we lift it up, poof! We'll see our shape printed on the paper, just like magic!

slides.text: 'Let's make a pattern! Star, space, star, space. Or star and heart, star and heart.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We made a star print! Now, let's make a pattern, which is like repeating something over and over. We can put a star, then a little space, then another star, or maybe we can put a star, then a heart, then a star, then a heart!

slides.prompt: Create a design using your potato stamps. Make a pattern, a border, or a picture using your prints!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to make your own art! You can use your potato stamps to make a fun pattern, a pretty border around your paper, or even a whole picture! You can make it look however you want, it's your special creation!

slides.text: Clean up. 'Potato printing has been used for hundreds of years. You are part of a long tradition!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create clear prints and attempt a repeating pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job making prints with our potato stamps! You are a super artist, and you even learned that people have been making art like this for a very, very long time. It's so cool that you made such beautiful patterns!

parent_notes: Potato printing is a wonderful introduction to relief printing — the same principle used in many traditional art forms. The adult should carve the potatoes (the knife is sharp), but the child does all the printing. Keep designs simple: geometric shapes, letters, or basic images. Potatoes can be reused for a day or two if stored in the refrigerator.

title: Geometric Cabinet — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori geometric cabinet. The child explores the first drawer of 2D shapes: circle, square, and triangle, learning to see and feel the difference between straight and curved edges.
instructions:
1. Present the first drawer of the geometric cabinet (demonstration tray with circle, square, triangle).
2. Remove the circle. Trace the edge with two fingers. 'A circle has a curved edge that goes around and around.'
3. Remove the square. Trace. 'A square has four straight edges and four corners.'
4. Remove the triangle. Trace. 'A triangle has three straight sides and three corners.'
5. Three-period lesson.
6. Match to the shape cards.
materials_needed: Geometric cabinet (first drawer) or demonstration tray

slides.heading: Geometric Cabinet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It tells us we're going to learn about some special shapes called the circle, the square, and the triangle. Aren't they exciting?

items: Geometric cabinet first drawer or demonstration tray
slides.setup_instructions: Place the drawer on the mat. Have shape cards nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our shape adventure! We have a special tray with holes for shapes, some cards with pictures of shapes, and a big mat to put everything on. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready!

slides.text: 'The geometric cabinet holds flat shapes — 2D shapes! Let's start with the first three.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our special shape box, and it holds the first shapes we're going to learn. We'll take them out one by one to see what they are. It's like unwrapping a surprise!

slides.text: Remove the circle inset. Trace the edge with two fingers: 'Round and round — no corners, no straight lines. This is a CIRCLE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take out this first shape. Feel its edge with your finger – it goes round and round, like a wheel! This shape is called a CIRCLE, and it doesn't have any pointy corners.

slides.text: Remove the square. Trace: 'Four straight sides, four corners — a SQUARE.' Remove the triangle. 'Three sides, three corners — TRIANGLE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's feel this one. It has sides that are straight, straight, straight, and it has pointy corners! This is a SQUARE. And this one has three straight sides and three corners – it's a TRIANGLE!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is a circle. Show me the triangle. What shape is this?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show me what you know! I'll say a shape name, and you point to it. Then, I'll point, and you tell me its name. We're playing a fun guessing game with the shapes!

slides.prompt: Trace each shape with your fingers. Then replace each inset in its frame. Match the shape cards to the insets.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's do a super fun activity! First, trace each shape with your finger, like we practiced. Then, put each shape back in its special spot in the tray. Finally, let's match the shape cards to the shapes in the tray – you can do it!

slides.text: 'Circle, square, triangle — the first three shapes in the geometric cabinet! There are many more to discover.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace, name, and replace all three shapes?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about the circle, the square, and the triangle today! We learned how to trace them, name them, and put them away. You're becoming a super shape expert!

parent_notes: The geometric cabinet contains drawers of 2D shape insets that the child handles and traces. Tracing the edge with two fingers gives a tactile impression of the shape — this is more powerful than just looking at a picture. The insets fit back into their frames, providing built-in error control. If you don't have a geometric cabinet, cut shapes from cardboard and trace their outlines on paper for matching.

title: Writing — First Pencil Words
description: The child begins writing CVC words with a pencil on lined paper. Transitioning from the moveable alphabet to actual handwriting.
instructions:
1. Review pencil grip: thumb, pointer, and middle finger.
2. Show lined paper. 'The letters sit on the bottom line.'
3. Child writes their name (if ready).
4. Dictate simple CVC words: cat, sun, bed. Child writes each.
5. Don't worry about perfection — celebrate the effort!
6. Let the child choose 2-3 words to write on their own.

slides.heading: Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Hello friend! Today we are going to learn how to write our very first words with a special tool called a pencil! It's going to be so much fun to see our words appear on paper!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a comfortable writing area. Place paper, pencil, and reference letters.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these things we need for writing today! We have a pencil for making marks, special paper with lines for our letters to sit on, and some letters to help us remember how they look. We also have a magic eraser in case we make a little oopsie!

slides.text: 'You've been building words with the moveable alphabet. Now let's try writing words with a PENCIL!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we used those letter pieces to build words? Now, we get to use a pencil to write those words all by ourselves! It's like magic, but you'll be the magician!

slides.text: Review the grip: 'Hold the pencil with three fingers — thumb, pointer, and middle. Rest it gently.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready to hold our pencil super strong! We use our thumb, our pointer finger, and our middle finger to hug the pencil. Like this, see? It helps us make nice, neat letters.

slides.text: 'Letters sit on this line.' Show where to write. Demonstrate writing 'cat' slowly. 'c-a-t — cat!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these lines on the paper? They are like little beds for our letters to sleep on. We put our letters right on the bottom line, just like this. Watch me write 'cat' — c-a-t. See how they all sit together on the line?

slides.text: 'Your turn! Listen to the word I say, think about the sounds, and write each letter.' Dictate: sun, bed, pig.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super writer! I'm going to say a word, and you listen to the sounds and write the letters. Let's try 'sun' first. What sounds do you hear?

slides.prompt: Write 5 words: cat, sun, bed, pig, dog. Then choose 2 words of YOUR choice and write them!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you are doing such a great job writing words! Now, let's write some more words like 'cat,' 'sun,' and 'bed.' After that, you can pick two of your favorite words to write all by yourself!

slides.text: 'You wrote REAL words with a pencil! Your hand is strong from all those metal insets and sewing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write at least 3 recognizable CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You wrote real words with a pencil, just like a big kid! Your hand is so strong from all the practice you've had, and you made amazing words today!

parent_notes: Moving from the moveable alphabet to pencil writing is a milestone. The child's hands have been prepared by metal insets, sewing, and practical life work. Expect letters to be large, uneven, and imperfect — this is completely normal. Wide-ruled paper provides generous space. Don't erase or correct — celebrate every attempt. Some children write spontaneously before this lesson; others need more time. Follow the child's readiness.

title: Skip Counting — By 2s and 5s
