description: The child learns to skip count by 2s (2, 4, 6, 8...) and by 5s (5, 10, 15, 20...) using bead chains and movement.
instructions:
1. Lay out objects in pairs: 'Count by twos! 2, 4, 6, 8, 10...'
2. Use a bead chain, marking every other bead.
3. 'This is skip counting — we skip one and count the next!'
4. Practice counting by 5s: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30.
5. Use hands: hold up 5 fingers, then 10, then 15...
6. Combine with movement: jump and count by 2s!

slides.heading: Skip Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! This is our special math lesson where we learn a super-fast way to count. We're going to learn how to count by 2s and 5s, which is like a secret code for numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Pair up objects for counting by 2s. Clear space for movement counting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these fun things we'll use! We have a string of beads, like a necklace, and we can also use little toys or blocks. We'll also need some space to jump around! Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things?

slides.text: 'Instead of counting 1, 2, 3, 4... we can SKIP! Watch: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10! We skipped the odd numbers!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Instead of counting every single number, we can skip some! Watch this: we go 2, then 4, then 6, then 8. We're jumping over some numbers to get to the next one faster! Isn't that neat?

slides.text: Show with paired objects: 'One pair is 2. Two pairs is 4. Three pairs is 6.' Count the pairs.
slides.mascot_explanation: See these little groups of toys? When we have one group, that's 2. When we have two groups, that's 4! We count them by groups of 2. It's like counting pairs of socks!

slides.text: 'Now let's count by FIVES! Like counting nickels! 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30.' Use hand groups.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to count by fives! Think about when you get a nickel, that's 5 cents. We count 5, then 10, then 15, just like counting money! We can use our fingers to help us too.

slides.text: Movement: 'Jump and count by 2s! Jump: 2! Jump: 4! Jump: 6! How high can we go?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our bodies moving! We're going to jump and count by 2s. Jump: 2! Jump: 4! Keep jumping and counting as high as you can go! Woohoo!

slides.prompt: Count by 2s to 20 with jumps. Count by 5s to 50 with claps. Can you go higher?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to play! We're going to jump and count by 2s all the way to 20. Then, we'll clap and count by 5s all the way to 50! Can you go even higher? You're doing so great!

slides.text: 'Skip counting is a shortcut! Instead of counting every number, we can count by groups.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child skip count by 2s to 20 and by 5s to 50?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned a super-fast way to count by 2s and 5s. It's like a shortcut for numbers! Remember how you jumped and counted all those numbers? That was amazing!

parent_notes: Skip counting is the foundation for multiplication. Counting by 2s leads to the 2 times table; counting by 5s leads to the 5 times table. Making it physical (jumping, clapping) helps the pattern stick. Practice skip counting during daily activities: going up stairs by 2s, counting coins by 5s, doing exercises by 2s. Singing skip counting songs is also very effective.

title: Seasons — Summer and Fall
description: Exploring summer and fall seasons to complete the four-season cycle. The child compares all four seasons and creates a seasonal wheel.
instructions:
1. Review winter and spring from the previous lesson.
2. Introduce summer: hot, long days, swimming, gardens full of flowers.
3. Introduce fall/autumn: cooling down, leaves change color, harvest time.
4. Sort picture cards into all four seasons.
5. Create a seasonal wheel: divide a circle into 4 parts, draw and label each season.
6. 'The seasons go in a circle — they repeat every year!'
materials_needed: Paper plate or large circle paper

slides.heading: The Seasons
slides.subheading: Summer, Fall, and the Seasonal Cycle
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It's all about the different times of the year, like when it's super sunny or when the leaves fall down. We're going to learn how they all go together like a big circle!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 4 sorting areas. Have picture cards from all seasons. Prepare a large circle divided into 4 sections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, Benny Bear, let's get our special things ready for our fun season game! We have some pretty pictures, a big paper plate that looks like a circle, and some colorful crayons. We also have four mats to help us sort our pictures. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: Review: 'We learned about winter and spring. Now let's learn the other two seasons!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we talked about winter with snow and spring with flowers? We're going to talk about the other two special times of the year now! It's like remembering our friends we met before.

slides.text: Summer: 'Hot! Long sunny days. Swimming, ice cream, gardens growing. The longest days of the year!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, summer is here! It's when it gets really warm and the sun shines for a long, long time, perfect for playing outside and eating yummy ice cream. We can go swimming too!

slides.text: Fall: 'Leaves change to red, orange, yellow. It gets cooler. Harvest time — apples, pumpkins!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about fall, or autumn! The leaves on the trees turn beautiful colors like red and yellow, and it feels a little cooler outside. It's also when we get yummy apples and pumpkins!

slides.text: 'The seasons go in a CYCLE: spring → summer → fall → winter → spring again! Around and around!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, the seasons are like a merry-go-round! They go in a circle: spring, then summer, then fall, and then winter, and then spring comes back again! It happens over and over all year long.

slides.prompt: Sort ALL the picture cards into 4 seasons. Then make a season wheel: draw one picture for each season in the circle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! Let's put all our season pictures in the right spots. After that, we'll draw a picture for each season on our big circle to make our very own season wheel! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Spring, summer, fall, winter — then it starts all over! The Earth keeps turning and the seasons keep cycling.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all four seasons in order and describe 2 characteristics of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about spring, summer, fall, and winter and how they go around and around like a circle. You are so smart for remembering them all! Wasn't making your own season wheel the coolest?

parent_notes: Completing the four-season cycle gives the child a framework for understanding the passage of time. The seasonal wheel (or seasonal circle) is a powerful visual: seasons are a cycle, not a line. Connect to the child's experience: 'What's your favorite season? What do you love about it?' A seasonal nature table that changes four times a year makes this tangible all year long.

title: Music — Rhythm Patterns with Body Percussion
description: The child learns to create and follow rhythm patterns using body percussion: clapping, stomping, patting knees, and snapping.
instructions:
1. Introduce body percussion: clap, stomp, pat knees, snap.
2. 'Let's make music with our bodies! No instruments needed!'
3. Create a simple pattern: clap-clap-stomp. Repeat 4 times.
4. Child creates their own pattern.
5. Call and response: I create a pattern, child repeats it.
6. Combine patterns into a 'body percussion song.'

slides.heading: Music
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the big word "Music"! That means we're going to make some happy sounds today. We'll learn about special beats, like a little drum inside our bodies.

slides.setup_instructions: Stand facing each other with space to move.
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? We don't need any toys or special things for this fun! All we need is YOU and ME and our amazing bodies. Let's stand up and get ready to wiggle and make some noise together!

slides.text: 'We can make music with our BODIES! Watch: CLAP, STOMP, PAT, SNAP. Those are our sounds!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen closely! We can make music with just our hands and feet! Watch me: I can clap my hands, stomp my feet, pat my knees, and even snap my fingers. These are our special music-making sounds!

slides.text: Simple pattern: 'Clap-clap-stomp. Clap-clap-stomp. Clap-clap-stomp. Clap-clap-stomp.' Repeat together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try a fun beat together! We'll go clap, clap, stomp, clap, clap, stomp. Let's do it four times, nice and loud! Ready? Clap, clap, stomp! You're doing so great!

slides.text: 'Now I'll make a pattern and YOU repeat it. Listen first, then copy.' (Call and response.)
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a game where I make a sound pattern, and you copy me! Listen first to my beat, and then you try to make the same sounds with your body. It's like a fun echo!

slides.text: 'Your turn! Make a pattern for ME to copy. You are the music leader!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's YOUR turn to be the music leader! You get to make up a fun beat for me to copy. Think of a pattern with our claps, stomps, and pats, and show me what you've got!

slides.prompt: Create a 4-beat body percussion pattern. Teach it to me! Then let's combine both our patterns into a song.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make a super cool song together! You make your own special beat, and then we'll put my beat and your beat together. You can do it, music leader!

slides.text: 'Rhythm is the heartbeat of music! You can make rhythm anywhere, anytime, with your own body.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create and repeat a 4-beat rhythm pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were so amazing at making music with your body! Remember how you clapped and stomped? That special beat is called rhythm, and it's like the happy heart of music. You can make rhythm anytime, anywhere!

parent_notes: Body percussion develops rhythm, coordination, and mathematical pattern thinking. It's also wonderfully accessible — no instruments needed. The call-and-response format (you create, child copies) builds auditory memory. Letting the child CREATE patterns and lead develops creativity and confidence. Connect rhythm to music you listen to together: 'Can you clap the beat of this song?'
